notes.text:
An update is now available for Red Hat OpenShift Application Runtimes.

Red Hat Product Security has rated this update as having a security impact of Important. A Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) base score, which gives a detailed severity rating, is available for each vulnerability. For more information, see the CVE links in the References section.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
Red Hat support for Spring Boot provides an application platform that reduces the complexity of developing and operating applications (monoliths and microservices) for OpenShift as a containerized platform.

This release of Red Hat support for Spring Boot 2.5.10 serves as a replacement for Red Hat support for Spring Boot 2.4.9, and includes bug fixes and enhancements. For more information, see the release notes listed in the References section.

Security Fix(es):

* undertow: client side invocation timeout raised when calling over HTTP2 (CVE-2021-3859)

* tomcat: Infinite loop while reading an unexpected TLS packet when using OpenSSL JSSE engine (CVE-2021-41079)

* tomcat: OutOfMemoryError caused by HTTP upgrade connection leak could lead to DoS (CVE-2021-42340)

* undertow: HTTP2SourceChannel fails to write final frame under some circumstances may lead to DoS (CVE-2021-3597)

* undertow: potential security issue in flow control over HTTP/2 may lead to DOS (CVE-2021-3629)

* wildfly-elytron: possible timing attack in ScramServer (CVE-2021-3642)

* tomcat: HTTP request smuggling when used with a reverse proxy (CVE-2021-33037)

* resteasy: Error message exposes endpoint class information (CVE-2021-20289)

* tomcat: JNDI realm authentication weakness (CVE-2021-30640)

For more details about the security issue(s), including the impact, a CVSS score, acknowledgments, and other related information, refer to the CVE page(s) listed in the References section.
notes.title: Details

notes.text: A flaw was found in undertow. The HTTP2SourceChannel fails to write the final frame under some circumstances, resulting in a denial of service. The highest threat from this vulnerability is availability.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: undertow: HTTP2SourceChannel fails to write final frame under some circumstances may lead to DoS
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: Red Hat OpenStack Platform's OpenDaylight will not be updated for this flaw because it was deprecated as of OpenStack Platform 14 and is only receiving security fixes for Important and Critical flaws.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

fixed: Red Hat Support for Spring Boot 2.5.10

remediations.details:
Before applying the update, back up your existing installation, including all applications, configuration files, databases and database settings, and so on.

The References section of this erratum contains a download link for the update. You must be logged in to download the update.

cwe.name: Generation of Error Message Containing Sensitive Information

notes.text: A flaw was found in RESTEasy in all versions of RESTEasy up to 4.6.0.Final. The endpoint class and method names are returned as part of the exception response when RESTEasy cannot convert one of the request URI path or query values to the matching JAX-RS resource method's parameter value. The highest threat from this vulnerability is to data confidentiality.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: A vulnerability in the JNDI Realm of Apache Tomcat allows an attacker to authenticate using variations of a valid user name and/or to bypass some of the protection provided by the LockOut Realm. This issue affects Apache Tomcat 10.0.0-M1 to 10.0.5; 9.0.0.M1 to 9.0.45; 8.5.0 to 8.5.65.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: tomcat: JNDI realm authentication weakness

cwe.name: Inconsistent Interpretation of HTTP Requests ('HTTP Request/Response Smuggling')

notes.text: Apache Tomcat 10.0.0-M1 to 10.0.6, 9.0.0.M1 to 9.0.46 and 8.5.0 to 8.5.66 did not correctly parse the HTTP transfer-encoding request header in some circumstances leading to the possibility to request smuggling when used with a reverse proxy. Specifically: - Tomcat incorrectly ignored the transfer encoding header if the client declared it would only accept an HTTP/1.0 response; - Tomcat honoured the identify encoding; and - Tomcat did not ensure that, if present, the chunked encoding was the final encoding.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: tomcat: HTTP request smuggling when used with a reverse proxy
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: Red Hat OpenStack Platform's OpenDaylight will not be updated for this flaw because it was deprecated as of OpenStack Platform 14 and is only receiving security fixes for Critical flaws.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

notes.text: A flaw was found in Apache Tomcat. When Tomcat was configured to use NIO+OpenSSL or NIO2+OpenSSL for TLS, a specially crafted packet can trigger an infinite loop, resulting in a denial of service. The highest threat from this vulnerability is to system availability.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: tomcat: Infinite loop while reading an unexpected TLS packet when using OpenSSL JSSE engine
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text:
In Red Hat Certificate System versions 9 and older, the version of Tomcat used is not affected by this flaw.
In Red Hat Certificate System 10, Tomcat is affected by this flaw. However, Tomcat is configured so that it does not use OpenSSLEngine, but the Dogtag JSS SSL implementation. As a result, the flaw can not be reached.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

cwe.name: Missing Release of Resource after Effective Lifetime

notes.text: A memory leak flaw was found in Apache Tomcat, where an HTTP upgrade connection does not release for WebSocket connections once the WebSocket connection is closed. If a sufficient number of such requests are made, an OutOfMemoryError occurs, leading to a denial of service. The highest threat from this vulnerability is to system availability.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: tomcat: OutOfMemoryError caused by HTTP upgrade connection leak could lead to DoS
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text:
Within Red Hat OpenStack Platform, Tomcat is provided as a component of OpenDaylight. This flaw will not receive a fix as OpenDaylight was deprecated as of OpenStack Platform 14 and is only receiving security fixes for Critical flaws.

Red Hat Satellite does not include the affected Apache Tomcat, however, Tomcat is shipped with Red Hat Enterprise Linux and consumed by the Candlepin component of Satellite. Red Hat Satellite users are therefore advised to check the impact state of Red Hat Enterprise Linux, since any necessary fixes will be distributed through the platform.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability
